description: A travelogue that explores India's coastline, delving into the significance of fish in various regional cultures, cuisines, and economies.

locations.description: The author visits Kolkata and describes the Howrah fish market, a labyrinth of open-fronted shops where fish like hilsa are sold. He investigates the cultural significance of fish in Bengali cuisine.
locations.note: Also shows up in Chapters 4 and 6.

locations.description: The author visits Diamond Harbour, another town known for its hilsa fish. He describes the town and his experience eating hilsa there.
The author travels to Hyderabad to learn about a unique asthma treatment involving live fish. He describes the city, the treatment, and the family who administers it.
The author visits the Church of the Holy Cross in Manapadu and describes the church, St. Francis Xavier's connection to the town, and the local fishing community.
The author travels to Tuticorin to learn about the history of the Parava community and their connection to fishing and Catholicism.

The author explores the fishing traditions and seafood cuisine of Tamil Nadu. The author also mentions Chennai as the home of Joe D'Cruz, a writer and businessman who provides insights into the Parava community.
The author travels to Kochi and observes the toddy shop culture, noting the scarcity of toddy shops in the region compared to southern Kerala.
locations.note: Also shows up in Chapters 4 and 6.

locations.description: The author visits Kozhikode and finds that the fiery cuisine and toddy shop culture persist in northern Kerala despite a higher Muslim population.
The author explores Mangalore's food scene, experiencing both disappointing tourist traps and delicious home-cooked meals, and learns about the Tamil fishing community's presence in the region.
The author visits Mumbai to experience the city's diverse food scene and learn about the Koli community's history and culture, particularly their relationship with the sea.
The author travels to Veraval, a major fishing port and boat-building center, to observe the traditional boat-building techniques.
The author visits Mangrol, another town known for its boat-building industry, and describes the harbor's crowded conditions and the longevity of the wooden boats built there.
The author visits the Shiva temple in Somnath and reflects on the vastness of the ocean and India's coastline.
Famous for its beaches and vibrant fishing culture, including spots like Fort Aguada.
An island known for its mangroves and fishing opportunities in the surrounding waters.
A popular beach town with a thriving fishing community and seafood restaurants.

title: Following Fish: Travels Around the Indian Coast
author: Samanth Subramanian

A fictional setting representing the oppressive home of Mr. Biswas' in-laws.

title: A House for Mr. Biswas
author: V. S. Naipaul

description: A reflective novel about a man who retreats to a remote cabin and recalls his childhood and the events that shaped his life.

locations.description: The rural landscape that serves as the backdrop for Trond's reflections.

title: Out Stealing Horses
author: Per Petterson

description: A travelogue of Murphy's journey through Laos in the late 1990s, exploring the country's culture and landscapes.

locations.description: Starting point of Murphy's journey in northern Laos.
A town Murphy visits on her way south.
Laos' capital city, where Murphy spends time exploring.
A major stop on Murphy's journey through southern Laos.
Site of ancient Khmer ruins visited by Murphy.

title: One Foot in Laos
author: Dervla Murphy

description: Rushdie's personal and political exploration of Nicaragua during the Sandinista revolution, blending travelogue and reportage.

locations.description: Rushdie's journey through Nicaragua during a politically volatile period.

title: The Jaguar Smile: A Nicaraguan Journey
author: Salman Rushdie

description: Polo's famous account of his travels through Asia, introducing medieval Europe to the cultures and wonders of the East.

locations.description: Marco Polo’s extensive travels across Asia, from China to Persia.

title: The Travels of Marco Polo
author: Marco Polo

description: A complex, multi-layered novel set in Spain, blending Gothic, picaresque, and philosophical elements.

locations.description: The mysterious and mountainous region where much of the novel's intricate stories unfold.

title: The Manuscript Found in Saragossa
author: Jan Potocki

description: A novel about the decline of a once-famous American novelist, set against the backdrop of Hollywood and the East Coast literary scene.

locations.description: The setting for part of the story, where the film industry contrasts with the literary world.

title: The Disenchanted
author: Budd Schulberg

description: A unique, experimental novel set in New Zealand, blending elements of mystery, cultural identity, and human connection.

locations.description: A coastal town in the South Island of New Zealand, central to the novel's setting.

title: The Bone People
author: Keri Hulme

description: O'Hanlon's entertaining narrative of his journey into the interior of Borneo, rich in natural history and humor.

locations.description: The remote and challenging journey into the heart of Borneo, full of wildlife and adventure.

title: Into the Heart of Borneo
author: Redmond O'Hanlon

description: A melancholic love story set in rural Japan, focusing on the relationship between a wealthy man and a geisha.

locations.description: A snowy hot spring town in rural Japan where the story takes place.

title: Snow Country
author: Yasunari Kawabata

description: Raban's account of his journey down the Mississippi River, exploring the river's history, ecology, and the people living along its banks.

locations.description: The river journey described in the book, focusing on its cultural and environmental significance.

title: Old Glory: A Voyage Down the Mississippi
author: Jonathan Raban

description: A travelogue of Syme's journey through the Middle East, exploring the region's history, culture, and religious significance.

locations.description: Syme’s exploration of the Middle East and its religious significance.

title: The Road to Mecca
author: Ronald Syme

description: A powerful story about the lives of African-American women in the early 20th century American South, dealing with issues of racism, sexism, and resilience.

locations.description: The rural setting where most of the novel takes place.

title: The Color Purple
author: Alice Walker

description: An essay recounting Huxley's experiences taking mescaline, exploring the nature of consciousness and perception.

locations.description: Huxley's exploration of perception took place in Los Angeles.

title: The Doors of Perception
author: Aldous Huxley

description: A noir detective novel featuring Philip Marlowe, filled with intrigue, corruption, and mystery in 1930s Los Angeles.
title: The Big Sleep
author: Raymond Chandler

description: Phillips' exploration of the Atlantic slave trade's legacy through visits to cities connected by this history.

locations.description: Phillips traces the routes and history of the Atlantic slave trade, visiting ports connected to this dark legacy.

title: The Atlantic Sound
author: Caryl Phillips

description: A satirical and humorous travelogue documenting Mark Twain’s travels through Europe and the Holy Land, filled with insightful and often biting commentary on the places and cultures encountered.

locations.description: One of Twain's first stops during his travels across Europe.
The Holy Land destination where Twain’s observations take on a more critical tone.

title: The Innocents Abroad
author: Mark Twain

description: A compelling narrative about the creation of the Oxford English Dictionary and the extraordinary collaboration between its chief editor and an imprisoned madman.

locations.description: The city where the Oxford English Dictionary was compiled.
The high-security mental hospital where one of the key figures in the book was imprisoned.

title: The Professor and the Madman
author: Simon Winchester
